required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Impact of Perivascular Tissue on Endothelial Function in Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting
clinical_study.official_title: Impact of Perivascular Tissue on Endothelial Function and Vessel Structure in Vein Grafts Used for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting: A Prospective, Randomized Controlled Trial.

lead_sponsor.agency: Norwegian University of Science and Technology

clinical_study.source: Norwegian University of Science and Technology

oversight_info.authority: Norway:National Committee for Medical and Health Research Ethics

brief_summary.textblock: The success of coronary artery bypass grafting is reliant on the quality of the grafts used. A new technique for harvesting veins used as grafts has been introduced. The study hypothesis is that veins harvested with this technique have an improved endothelial function.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.description: Graft function as evaluated by coronary angiography

secondary_outcome.description: The following measures will be assessed at a 6 week follow up: Signs of infection Wound dehiscence Aesthetics Cutaneous sensory loss Wound discomfort

secondary_outcome.measure: Postoperative complications related to cardiac surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Major adverse cardiac and cerebral events Postoperative complications Reoperation Sternal dehiscence Mediastinitis

arm_group.description: no-touch technique of harvesting the saphenous vein graft for coronary artery bypass grafting
conventional technique of harvesting the saphenous vein graft for coronary artery bypass grafting

intervention.description: The saphenous vein is exposed by a longitudinal incision, and all visible side branches ligated. The vein is then isolated together with a pedicle of surrounding tissue and left in situ until extracorporeal circulation is started to allow continuous heparinized blood perfusion. After removal, the vein is stored in blood obtained from the aortic cannula before cooling. To check for leakage from side branches and the distal anastomosis, the proximal end of the graft is briefly connected to the arterial cannula.

The saphenous vein is exposed by a longitudinal leg incision, skeletonized from surrounding tissue, and side branches ligated. The vein is removed from the leg immediately after dissection, manually distended with saline using a syringe and stored in saline at room temperature, according to standard procedure at St. Olav's Hospital.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Isolated elective, primary CABG requiring cardiopulmonary bypass
- Left ventricular ejection fraction >35%
- at least one saphenous vein graft required as part of revascularization strategy
Exclusion Criteria:
- Acute or chronic inflammatory diseases
- Malignancies
- Pregnancy
- Previous cardiac surgery
- Serum creatinine >120 μmol/L
- Coagulopathy
- Insulin dependent diabetes mellitus
- Smoking during last 6 months
- Leg not suitable for No-touch vein harvesting as judged by the operator.
- Need for nitrates on operation day
- not receiving statins

overall_official.affiliation: Norwegian University of Science and Technology
